channel.title: StockHedges
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from StockHedges, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Shares of Cartier owner Richemont jump 16% as sales rise in December quarter
item.description: Cartier owner Richemont on Thursday reported a 10% increase in third quarter sales even as China demand weighed.

item.title: With Switch 2 and 'Mario Kart,' Nintendo Sticks to its Winning Formula
item.description: Past product launches hold valuable lessons for the company.

item.title: TSMC net profit hits record high as fourth-quarter results top expectations on robust AI chip demand
item.description: TSMC, the world's largest contract chip manufacturer, produces advanced processors for clients such as Nvidia and Apple and has benefited from the meg...

item.title: The Year That Hedge Funds Got Their Mojo Back
item.description: In a year when everything seemed to go up, the industry generated some of its strongest returns in a decade. Was 2024 a real turning point?

item.title: Trump Launches Meme Coin Ahead of White House Return
item.description: Surging token had a market cap above $6 billion as of Saturday evening.

item.title: Morgan Stanley tops estimates on strong equities and fixed income trading revenue
item.description: While bank stocks have been supported by enthusiasm for rising deal activity, it was actually the trading side that helped Morgan Stanley more in the ...

item.title: Bank of America tops estimates on better-than-expected investment banking, interest income
item.description: The company said fourth-quarter profit more than doubled to $6.67 billion, or 82 cents per share, from a year earlier.

item.title: Here's what it will take for Apple to get out of its 2025 funk
item.description: Evercore ISI said China may be a "key wildcard" for Apple during the company's upcoming fiscal Q1 release on Jan. 30.

item.title: The Great Wealth Transfer Is Being Powered by Women
item.description: With baby boomers aging and the gender gap in lifespans growing, more women have the final word on how the family nest egg gets parceled out.

item.title: Banks Scrimped on Customer Interest. Now They're Paying for It.
item.description: Brokerages paid next to nothing for cash in accounts even after the Fed started raising rates.
